Employment

Getting Fired / Wrongful Termination

What to know about your rights when terminated from employment

Your Rights

5 rights in this scenario

Your employer cannot fire you because of your race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age (40+), disability, or because you reported illegal activity. Discriminatory termination is illegal. If you were fired and suspect discrimination, document the timeline and keep performance reviews, emails, and witness information.

Source: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA), ADA

You are entitled to all wages you've earned up to your termination date. Timing varies by stateâ€”some require immediate payment, others allow a final paycheck on the next regular payday. Employers cannot withhold earned wages as punishment. Check your state's specific timeline requirements.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: State Wage and Hour Laws and Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)

If your employer has 20+ employees, you can continue your group health insurance for up to 18 months after termination by paying the premium yourself (usually about 102% of the employer's cost). COBRA helps bridge the gap until you get new coverage. Your employer must notify you of this right.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA) of 1985

You cannot be fired for reporting illegal activity, safety violations, environmental crimes, or other unlawful conduct to government agencies or law enforcement. This protection applies even if you report internally first. Whistleblowers have legal remedies including reinstatement and damages.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: Whistleblower Protection Act (OSH Act Â§ 11(c)), Sarbanes-Oxley, Dodd-Frank

If you are fired without cause, you can apply for unemployment insurance benefits. You'll receive a percentage of your previous wages for a limited period (typically 26 weeks). Apply immediately after termination. Your employer may contest your claim, but if you were fired unfairly, benefits are likely approved.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: State Unemployment Insurance Laws and Federal UI Framework
